title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Can we pause a moment to appreciate the excellent work that independent and university presses consistently put out? That’s no knock on the so-called Big Five — the publishing conglomerates who dominate the industry the way the 1990s Yankees dominated baseball — but given the discrepancy in resources and depth, I’ll always nurture a soft spot for the scrappy small-market teams who hold their own. (In publishing, they don’t necessarily come from literal small markets: There are plenty of impressive indies right here in New York City.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Haley Hits DeSantis on Disney: Government Shouldn’t ‘Bully’ Companies
description: The former South Carolina governor cast the Florida governor as anti-business.
content: It was a feud that cost Florida 2,000 jobs under Gov. Ron DeSantis. And Nikki Haley pounced.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Does Learning to Be a Good Writer Still Matter in the Age of A.I.?

content: Are you a good writer? Do you enjoy the craft?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inflation Is Moderating, but Pressure Remains on Biden
description: Voters have taken a downbeat view of the economy because costs have remained stubbornly high.
content: President Biden has yet to benefit from moderating inflation, and data set for release on Thursday could complicate the White House’s attempts to show progress on rising prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: U.S. Military Aid to Ukraine Was Poorly Tracked, Pentagon Report Says
description: The report found that American officials and diplomats had failed to quickly or fully account for all of the nearly 40,000 weapons sent to the front.
content: More than $1 billion worth of shoulder-fired missiles, kamikaze drones and night-vision goggles that the United States has sent to Ukraine have not been properly tracked by American officials, a new Pentagon report concluded, raising concerns that they could be stolen or smuggled at a time when Congress is debating whether to send more military aid to Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Seeks Details of Atlanta Prosecutor’s Communications with Biden Aides
description: Nathan Wade talked to White House staff members in 2022, when he was seeking witnesses for the investigation into whether Donald J. Trump interfered in the 2020 election in Georgia.
content: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump are seeking more information about discussions Atlanta prosecutors had with the Biden White House, as well as with the House committee that investigated the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

title: State Legislators, Wary of Deceptive Election Ads, Tighten A.I. Rules
description: Sophisticated political deepfakes have warped elections overseas. Can U.S. legislators act fast enough to make A.I. campaign ads more transparent?
content: When experts in artificial intelligence recently showed a gathering of state legislators a deepfake image that had been generated by A.I. in early 2022, depicting former presidents Donald J. Trump and Barack Obama playing one-on-one basketball, the crowd chuckled at how rudimentary it was.

title: Elmore Nickleberry, 92, Sanitation Worker in ’68 Memphis Strike, Dies
description: He was one of the last survivors of a historic walkout that demanded respect and a living wage and that drew Martin Luther King to their cause.
content: Elmore Nickleberry, one of the last living participants in the Memphis sanitation workers’ strike of 1968, a historic walkout that sought to win respect and equal rights for African American workers and that drew the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King to their side, died on Dec. 30 in Memphis. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Did This Couple Inspire Edward Albee’s ‘Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf’?
description: A newly preserved Andy Warhol film documents a combative artist couple the playwright knew. The movie is premiering in MoMA’s To Save and Project.
content: Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton put their marital demons on film in “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” (1966). But neither they nor their director, Mike Nichols, can take credit for being the first to try to bring Edward Albee’s 1962 play to the screen, or even for being the first movie couple to draw on their own real-life discord in that context.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Caitlin O'Keefe and Elisa Gutierrez
title: ‘Right Where We Want Him, 30 Points Up’: Chasing Trump in Iowa
description: A look at Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley’s quest to catch the former president — and finish ahead in their race for second place.
content: At the start of the 2024 Republican primary campaign, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida was considered by many in his party to be the biggest threat to Donald Trump. He was seen as someone who could win over the voters who were tired of Trump’s antics, and also bring along the MAGA movement. But it didn’t work out that way. And as Mr. DeSantis has struggled, one main opponent, former Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina, has seen her star — and her standing in the polls — rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Marisa Pavan, Oscar Nominee for ‘The Rose Tattoo,’ Dies at 91
description: The twin sister of the Italian ingénue Pier Angeli, she attempted to avoid the pitfalls of fame that befell her sister’s career.
content: The Italian actress Marisa Pavan never achieved the fame of her twin sister, Pier Angeli, a film ingénue of the 1950s who graced national magazine covers, and whose romance with James Dean and subsequent marriage to the singer Vic Damone became the stuff of Hollywood lore.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Maryland Elections Official Resigns After Arrest in Jan. 6 Attack
description: Carlos Ayala, a member of the Maryland State Board of Elections, was charged in the District of Columbia with civil disorder, a felony, for participating in the breach of the Capitol in 2021.
content: A Maryland elections board official resigned this week after he was arrested on federal charges related to his participation in the breach of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Missiles Strike Targets in Yemen Linked to the Houthi Militia
description: The American-led strikes came in response to more than two dozen Houthi drone and missile attacks against commercial shipping in the Red Sea since the Israel-Hamas war began.
content: The United States and five of its allies on Thursday carried out military strikes against more than a dozen targets in Yemen controlled by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia, in an expansion of the war in the Middle East that the Biden administration had sought to avoid for the past three months.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Parade of Unsettled Weather Will Continue Into the Weekend
description: Severe weather will again sweep the South, while blizzard conditions are forecast to hit the Midwest starting Friday. Some cities will see subzero temperatures through the long weekend.
content: There has been a pretty remarkable parade of intense storm systems this past week, Greg Carbin, the branch chief of forecast operations for the National Weather Service, said on Wednesday. And it isn’t over.

title: Will You Vote for Trump Again?
description: It’s the question weighing on Republicans across the country. But Iowans get to decide first. We listened as they grappled with their choices.
content: There is no way around it: The Iowa caucuses on Monday, the kickoff of the 2024 presidential election, are not really about competing visions for the future of the Republican Party. They are not a battle between dueling ideologies or policy priorities or America’s role in the world.

content: Throughout the Trump presidency, Amalija Knavs — mother to first lady Melania Trump — was something of a mysterious figure. Mrs. Knavs, who died earlier this week, rarely made public comments or gave interviews. Striking and perfectly coifed, Mrs. Knavs was a recurring but almost entirely silent presence during the Trump presidency, much like her daughter.

content: Lynn Yamada Davis, a TikTok creator who brought joy to millions of people with her zany style and cooking tips on her account, Cooking With Lynja, died on Jan. 1 at Riverview Medical Center in New Jersey. She was 67 and lived in Holmdel, N.J.

description: He and his sister became child stars in the 1950s by making exuberantly unhinged music. “I had so much energy,” he said, “they didn’t know what to do with me.”
content: Larry Collins, the prodigious child guitarist who worked with his sister Lorrie as the exuberant 1950s rockabilly duo the Collins Kids, died on Friday in Santa Clarita, Calif. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Some People Keep Serious Illnesses Private
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III is under scrutiny for concealing his prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment. But experts say it can be a common coping mechanism.
content: The U.S. defense secretary is facing scrutiny after failing to immediately disclose to the White House his recent prostate-cancer diagnosis and a related hospitalization, a breach of protocol for which he has apologized.

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: Scaly Fossil Is the Oldest-Known Piece of Skin
description: The specimen came from a 289 million-year-old fossil deposit and might offer clues to how skin evolved.
content: Dry, scaly skin may be one of the least fun parts of winter. But in the broad scheme of things, a tough, watertight hide is part of what enabled the ancestors of modern reptiles, birds and mammals to move inland while their thin-skinned amphibian cousins remained close to water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Sokolove
title: The All-Time-Great Coach Who Makes Football Fun
description: Andy Reid’s diligence and sense of mischief have made him one of the game’s best-ever coaches. Can he get his struggling Chiefs back to the Super Bowl?
content: Andy Reid, the coach of the Kansas City Chiefs, has won more than 250 games in his career, fourth all-time, which puts him high on any list of the N.F.L.’s greatest coaches. Most of the others in that pantheon are men who personify the sport’s militaristic soul — Vince Lombardi, for example, the fabled coach of the 1960s-era Green Bay Packers, or Reid’s contemporary, the grim Bill Belichick of the New England Patriots. But Reid is no Lombardi or Belichick; he’s Steve Jobs. He’s a designer, a tinkerer, a product engineer who imbues his football with creativity and even an occasional touch of whimsy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Daring to Create Art Freely Behind the Iron Curtain
description: The Walker Art Center stages a rare survey of the courageous work that bloomed in the Eastern bloc, as artists struggled against state repression.
content: To say what you want, to act how you want, to live and fear no reprisals: there are some rights you can start to take for granted. Liberal democracy has been having a rough ride this century, and maybe it was inevitable, as elite institutions sputtered and populist reaction mounted, that some American artists and writers would forget just why free expression matters. Why has the recent reaction to free-speech hypocrisy and misinformation, at least in some cultural sectors, been to denigrate free speech itself? From Turkey to China and India to Zimbabwe, artists still face censorship, lawsuits, imprisonment or worse for the crime of creativity; perhaps some of us are too comfortable to take it seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

description: The entertainment behemoth’s latest series for Disney+ minimizes superheroics in favor of Southwestern noir, but there’s a tug of war between its action-thriller and cultural-historical imperatives.
content: Maya Lopez is, in the Marvel television universe, a deaf Choctaw girl whose mother dies and whose father then moves from Oklahoma to New York City to work for a criminal kingpin (conveniently known as Kingpin). After her father also dies, Maya — embittered and alienated — is groomed for a life of crime by Kingpin and becomes a deadly underworld enforcer. author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Mean Girls’ Review: ‘Get in, Loser,’ Regina George Is Back
description: Still puffily padded but no longer particularly tart, this shape-shifting classic about the girls you love to hate retains its ingratiating charms.
content: Can a movie musical based on a Broadway musical based on a film comedy that in turn was based on a parenting book be any good? Sure — if only because the writer-producer Tina Fey and the producer Lorne Michaels have made sure that little has changed in their money-printing property since the first movie hit theaters in 2004. Few stories, it turns out, are as comically and horrifyingly reliable as those set in high school; few villains are as dependably hissable as a desirable young woman with an ostensibly cold heart.

content: Kali Uchis basks in pleasure on her fourth studio album, “Orquídeas.” Make that pleasures: carnal, material, romantic, sonic, competitive and, if necessary, vengeful, all with a girlish nonchalance. The album begins with loops of laughter and ethereal oohs and ahs; it ends with Uchis thanking listeners with a “mwah” kiss. It’s an album of breezy confidence and sly ingenuity, easily moving among futuristic electronics, 1990s nostalgia and Latin roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israel and Hamas Are in Talks to Deliver Medicine to Hostages in Gaza
description: More than 120 hostages are believed to still be held in Gaza and many suffer from health conditions that require regular medical care.
content: Qatar is engaged in high-level discussions with Hamas to deliver vital prescription medicines to Israeli hostages in the Gaza Strip at the same time it is making progress with Israel about allowing more medicine into the enclave for Gazan civilians, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Grand Jury Declines to Indict Ohio Woman Who Miscarried at Home
description: In a case that had drawn international attention, Brittany Watts had been charged with abuse of a corpse after miscarrying and disposing of the nonviable fetus.
content: A grand jury in Ohio on Thursday declined to indict a woman who had miscarried a nonviable fetus at home on a felony charge of abuse of a corpse, ending a case that had drawn international scrutiny from lawyers and reproductive health advocates who had argued the charge was baseless and could endanger other patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: ‘I’m Not Going to Have Time for Retribution,’ Trump Says at Town Hall
description: The town hall on Fox News was the former president’s counterprogramming as Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis debated on CNN.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, who for months has expressed openness to retaliating against his political enemies if he returns to the White House and has vowed to have federal prosecutors investigate them, downplayed his interest in pursuing retribution at a televised town hall on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: How Much Space Do You Get for $1,700 a Month?
description: The average national rent affords a wildly varied amount of space from city to city.
content: The past year gave many house hunters a sobering realization: For now, they remain among the ranks of renters. While 2023 also came with a slight easing of competition among renters and somewhat lower rents, the market remains tight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Chris Christie Goes Down Swinging at Trump and Pleading With His Party
description: As he ended his presidential campaign, Mr. Christie became the latest member of the Republican old guard to deliver a dark warning about the danger of Donald Trump.
content: Chris Christie closed out his second presidential campaign much as he began it, with a blistering and personal takedown of Donald J. Trump designed to prompt a reckoning in his party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Will Chatbots Teach Your Children?
description: New A.I. tools could enable a Silicon Valley dream: bots that customize learning for pupils. Prior attempts have not lived up to the hype.
content: Sal Khan, the chief executive of Khan Academy, gave a rousing TED Talk last spring in which he predicted that A.I. chatbots would soon revolutionize education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Drought Touches a Quarter of Humanity, U.N. Says, Disrupting Lives Globally
description: The crisis, worsened partly by climate change, has been accompanied by soaring food prices and could have consequences for hunger, elections and migration worldwide.
content: Pandemic. War. Now drought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Crime on the Decline
description: Murders likely fell at record speed last year.
content: In the chaotic early months of the Covid pandemic, when the U.S. was also going through the aftermath of George Floyd’s murder, violent crime rose across the country. Murders in 2020 increased at the fastest rate since national statistics began in 1960. Other crimes, like shootings and car thefts, also increased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Former Cardinal Is Ruled Not Competent to Stand Trial in Sex Abuse Case
description: Theodore McCarrick was the highest-ranking cleric in the nation to face criminal charges in the Catholic church’s sprawling abuse scandal.
content: The criminal case against a former cardinal who was once one of the most prominent and revered Catholic leaders in the country was suspended Wednesday, possibly ending efforts to prosecute him on sex abuse charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man Reaches $25 Million Settlement After 44 Years of Wrongful Imprisonment
description: The city of Concord, N.C., acknowledged that “significant errors in judgment and willful misconduct” led to the wrongful conviction of Ronnie Long, 68, on rape and burglary charges.
content: A man who spent 44 years in prison after a jury in North Carolina wrongfully convicted him of raping a woman in 1976 has settled a lawsuit against state and local law enforcement officials for $25 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: DeSantis and Haley Clash Over Military Aid to Ukraine
description: Nikki Haley said U.S. aid to Ukraine was essential to preventing a broader conflict, while Ron DeSantis said he didn’t want the U.S. to be dragged into a war with no clear end.
content: After about 30 minutes of debate featuring repeated promotions of campaign websites and dozens of permutations of the word “lie,” Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and Nikki Haley diverged on actual policy: the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: Haley Created a Site to Fact-Check DeSantis. It Could Use More Context.
description: During this week’s debate in Iowa, Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, tirelessly promoted a website to fact-check Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. We took a closer look, and here’s what we found.
content: More than a dozen times during Wednesday night’s Republican presidential debate, Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, directed viewers to a website purporting to correct what she called Ron DeSantis’s “lies.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Biden’s Appeal to Black Voters Needs an Overhaul
description: The president’s speech at Mother Emanuel was a missed opportunity.
content: Let’s start here: A second Donald Trump presidency is a disaster scenario.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: What Happens When There Is No Food: Experts Say Severe Malnutrition Could Set in Swiftly in Gaza
description: Nutrition experts say the progression from hunger to severe malnutrition can be rapid, especially in children.
content: A panel of experts affiliated with the United Nations has warned that the population of the Gaza Strip is at imminent risk of famine, with more than 90 percent of its 2.2 million people facing “acute food insecurity” and a quarter of the population experiencing “catastrophic levels of hunger.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: A Use-What-You-Have Frittata That Won’t End Up a Mess
description: Sohla El-Waylly’s cheesy frittata recipe is as foolproof as it is versatile.
content: As Emily Weinstein says in this week’s Five Weeknight Dishes newsletter — you are subscribed to Five Weeknight Dishes, yes? — a dish like a frittata, that clean-out-the-fridge standard, walks a fine line between delicious and disaster. This new cheesy frittata recipe from Sohla El-Waylly, however, keeps you safely on the stellar side of things, since it comes with a video of Sohla walking you through every step. (She also explains the differences between all those terms on egg cartons and has more kitchen tips to share: 11, to be exact.) The recipe is clear, informative and friendly — everything you’d expect from a series called Cooking 101.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Tackling Climate Change in the Birthplace of Oil
description: Azerbaijan is where the petroleum era began.
content: For the second year in a row, the United Nations climate summit known as COP will take place in a petrostate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Many Laws to Protect Sharks Have Backfired, Researchers Find
description: A few countries have successful policies, but well-intentioned rules in others appear to have inadvertently increased demand for shark meat.
content: Many of the policies enacted around the world to curb the mass killing of sharks have backfired, partly because well-intentioned rules against taking the predators solely for their fins have led to an increase in demand for shark meat, according to a study published on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Scotland, Joining England and Wales, Will Restrict Bully XL Dogs
description: The dogs, seen as dangerous by many, will have to be muzzled in public, neutered and microchipped, among other regulations.
content: Scotland will join England and Wales in strictly regulating the bully XL dog breed, after some of the dog breed owners in those two countries scrambled to send their dogs north to avoid rules already in place at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alicia Napierkowski
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Greenwich, Conn.
content: A four-bedroom, six-and-a-half-bath, 4,990-square-foot house built in 1925, with a covered entryway; a formal living room with a fireplace and deck access; an expansive eat-in kitchen with marble countertops, built-ins, original exposed brick and a butler’s pantry; an en suite primary bedroom with west-facing windows, chair rail molding and a walk-in closet; a walk-out lower-level workshop and office with a private entrance and driveway, full bath and mudroom that leads outside to the in-ground pool; on 0.93 acres surrounded by the Ardsley Country Club golf course. William Ford-Sussman, Coldwell Banker Realty, 914-420-6161, coldwellbankerhomes.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Scientists Scramble to Keep Dog Aging Project Alive
description: The National Institute on Aging may let funding lapse for a yearslong study of nearly 50,000 pet dogs, which could also offer insight into human health.
content: In late 2019, scientists began searching for 10,000 Americans willing to enroll their pets in an ambitious new study of health and longevity in dogs. The researchers planned to track the dogs over the course of their lives, collecting detailed information about their bodies, lifestyles and home environments. Over time, the scientists hoped to identify the biological and environmental factors that kept some dogs healthy in their golden years — and uncover insights about aging that could help both dogs and humans lead longer, healthier lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo and Ivan Penn
title: As Utility Bills Rise, Low-Income Americans Struggle for Access to Clean Energy
description: The Biden administration has deployed various programs to try to increase access to clean energy. But systems that could help lower bills are still out of reach for many low-income households.
content: Cindy Camp is one of many Americans facing rising utility costs. Ms. Camp, who lives in Baltimore with three family members, said her gas and electric bills kept “going up and up” — reaching as high as $900 a month. Her family has tried to use less hot water by doing fewer loads of laundry, and she now eats more fast food to save on grocery bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Secretary Austin Should Resign
description: The issue here is maintaining standards, not passing judgment.
content: I have great respect for Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin. He has served the United States honorably and heroically for decades. He earned a Silver Star during the invasion of Iraq in 2003. He commanded American forces during the successful counteroffensive against ISIS. He has done his job admirably, helping shepherd the United States through two of the most dangerous international military crises in decades. Nonetheless, he should resign or, failing that, be fired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: Looming Starvation in Gaza Shows Resurgence of Civilian Sieges in Warfare
description: A U.N.-affiliated panel said the territory could tip into famine very soon. International laws to protect people from human-made famines offer little help.
content: The number of people facing possible starvation in the Gaza Strip in the coming weeks is the largest share of a population at risk of famine identified anywhere since a United Nations-affiliated panel created the current global food-insecurity assessment 20 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Sununu Commits to Backing Trump if He Is the G.O.P. Nominee
description: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire, a Trump critic who has endorsed Nikki Haley, said that if the former president won the nomination he would support him, even if convicted.
content: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire, who has been a vocal critic of former President Donald J. Trump, nonetheless committed on Wednesday to supporting him if he won the Republican nomination, even if he were convicted of a felony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes and Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Four Festival Shows Offering Soul-Enriching Experiments in Theater
description: Buckle up for “Open Mic Night” and “Search Party” at Under the Radar and two wildly adventurous works at the Exponential Festival.
content: For about two-thirds of Peter Mills Weiss and Julia Mounsey’s new show, “Open Mic Night,” Weiss alternated between reminiscing about a now-closed space and asking audience members a series of rapid-fire questions, like “Vipers or moles?” “Vacation or voting?” Mounsey was sitting behind a laptop, which she used to drop sound cues, and the blinding house lights remained on as Weiss engaged in crowd work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: I Have Covid. Should I Take Paxlovid?
description: We asked experts about who should take the antiviral medication, how well it works and where to get it for free.
content: As hospitalizations and deaths from Covid-19 rise, fueled by a fast-moving new variant that now accounts for a majority of U.S. cases, Paxlovid can help protect patients from some of the worst outcomes of the illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Adam Sella and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Inspections, Bottlenecks and Safety Concerns Hinder Gaza Aid
description: Obstacles at two border crossings are exacerbating a growing humanitarian crisis, according to two U.S. senators and officials with the U.N. and other groups.
content: The trucks carrying aid for Gaza stop for exhaustive inspections by Israeli authorities. They can pass through two border crossings only during limited hours. Inside the territory, vehicles travel over a landscape of rubble and ruined roads to distribute the aid to desperate, hungry crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Richard Fausset
title: Lawyer Tapped to Prosecute Trump in Georgia Is Now Under Scrutiny Himself
description: Nathan Wade has stayed silent since a legal filing said he was chosen for the job because he was romantically involved with the Fulton County district attorney.
content: Before he became the special prosecutor leading the Georgia election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump, Nathan Wade was working as a private defense lawyer and a judge for a municipal court in the Atlanta suburbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: What Does a Hard-Boiled Detective Do in Retirement?
description: In “Monsieur Spade,” a new AMC show, Clive Owen plays the inscrutable Sam Spade, attempting to put his past behind him in the South of France.
content: In an early scene in “Monsieur Spade,” a new six-part series from AMC, the American detective Sam Spade, played by Clive Owen, is lying on his side, grimacing as a doctor examines his nether regions. “Best prostate of the morning,” the doctor says cheerfully, snapping off his rubber gloves. Then he motions Spade his office to tell him he has emphysema and must stop smoking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Civil Conversation
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei
title: ‘Frozen Garlic!’ Taiwan Likes Its Democracy Loud and Proud
description: At the island’s election rallies, warming up the crowd for candidates is crucial. “You have to light a fire in their hearts,” one host says.
content: Huang Chen-yu strode onto an outdoor stage in a southern Taiwanese county, whooping and hollering as she roused the crowd of 20,000 into a joyous frenzy — to welcome a succession of politicians in matching jackets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Zachary Small
title: Field Museum Covers Some Native Displays as New Rules Take Effect
description: The Chicago institution’s move is in response to updated federal regulations that require museums to consult with tribes before exhibiting Native American cultural items.
content: The Field Museum in Chicago has covered up several display cases that feature Native American cultural items in response to new federal regulations that require museums to obtain consent from tribes before exhibiting objects connected to their heritage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘Visible Mending’
description: What can knitting teach us about embracing life’s messy imperfections?
content: “Visible Mending” is a nine-minute animated film about the simple but extraordinary power of knitting and how the craft can help us heal, even at our most broken. As one older knitter says, “When your life is sort of falling apart you need to create a purpose in it for yourself. And if that purpose is quite small, it doesn’t matter. It’s important. It’s something tangible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: In the Bronx, Trump’s Name Is Replaced at a Golf Course
description: The removal of the sign by the golf course’s new owner, Bally’s Corporation, was another example of Trump’s withdrawal from New York City.
content: As closing arguments began in President Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud trial in Manhattan on Thursday, his name disappeared from a golf course in the Bronx that had long welcomed drivers to the borough with a large sign reading “TRUMP LINKS.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: What to Watch This Weekend: A Powerful Australian Drama
description: Newly arrived to Hulu, the brisk four-part series stars Aisha Dee of “The Bold Type.”
content: Aisha Dee (“The Bold Type”) stars in “Safe Home,” now on Hulu, a brisk Australian miniseries about domestic violence that blends a few formats, sometimes to powerful effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Bottled Water Is Full of Plastic Particles. Can They Harm Your Health?
description: Here’s what scientists know so far about the health effects of nanoplastics, and what you can do to reduce your exposure.
content: A liter of bottled water contains nearly a quarter of a million pieces of nanoplastic on average, according to new research published this week in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Six Degrees of Self-Help, Nora Ephron and ‘Mommie Dearest’
description: Fifty years ago this week, “How to Be Your Own Best Friend” nipped at the heels of “The Joy of Sex.” Here’s the story behind its longevity.
content: “How do people get to be the insecure, weak, self-deprecating wretches to whom this book is addressed?” Harry Schwartz wrote in his Times review of “How to Be Your Own Best Friend,” a self-help book that celebrated its 26th week as a best seller 50 years ago this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucky Benson
title: Clown Cardio Doesn’t Take Exercise Seriously
description: Fitness and improv unite to form one wacky workout in — where else? — Los Angeles.
content: Whenever Alex Lee mentions Clown Cardio, he is met with some confusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Judge in Trump’s Civil Fraud Trial Is Swatted at His Home
description: Authorities responded to a fake bomb threat at the home of Justice Arthur F. Engoron on the day he was set to hear closing arguments in New York’s suit against Donald Trump.
content: Nassau County authorities on Thursday responded to a hoax bomb threat at the house of the judge presiding over the civil fraud trial of Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Christie’s Exit Should Give Haley a Chance in New Hampshire. Will It Be Enough?
description: A group of moderate voters is now available, but it may not put her over the top against Trump.
content: Eight years ago, Chris Christie gave Donald J. Trump the biggest political assist of the 2016 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Chris Christie, We Miss You!
description: Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis summon the right fury for the wrong target.
content: I wish Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis had shown a quarter as much contempt for Donald Trump as they did for each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘The Book of Clarence’ Review: Messiahs Wherever You Look
description: LaKeith Stanfield leads a predominantly Black cast in a retelling of the story of Jesus that’s both irreverent and devoted.
content: The subject of a Jesus movie is technically Jesus. But every movie based on the biblical account of Jesus — and there are many such movies, stretching back to 1898 — says at least as much about the people who made it as it does about the man himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Hunter Biden Pleads Not Guilty to Tax Evasion Charges
description: A judge set a tentative trial date for June 20, raising the possibility that Mr. Biden could be on trial twice in the thick of the 2024 presidential campaign.
content: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, pleaded not guilty on Thursday to charges of evading taxes on millions in income from foreign businesses, six months after the collapse of a plea deal that would have brought an end to the long-running investigation into him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Mexican Whiskey Is on the Rise, Powered by Ancient Corn
description: Several distillers are using local heirloom grain and exporting to the United States, the heart of another corn-based spirit: bourbon.
content: Of the 59 varieties of native corn in Mexico, nal t’eel is one of the oldest, having emerged in the Yucatán Peninsula some 4,000 years ago. It grows quickly, largely unbothered by heavy rains or drought — so robust that the Mayans called it “rooster corn.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Kim Reynolds Has Another Account, @Kimberl26890376, and Opinions About Donald Trump
description: In recent months, the Republican governor of Iowa has used a secondary account on X to share her unfiltered feelings on the Republican presidential primary race.
content: Not long after the calendar turned to 2024, Kim Reynolds, the Republican governor of Iowa, signed into X, the platform formerly known as Twitter, and posted about the presidential primary, where she has emerged as a key backer of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida over former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Bud Harrelson, Shortstop for ‘Miracle Mets’ of 1969, Dies at 79
description: An outstanding fielder, he helped the team win the World Series that year and reach another in 1973. He stayed with the Mets as a coach and, briefly, manager.
content: Bud Harrelson, the slick-fielding shortstop who helped take the Mets to their astonishing 1969 World Series championship and the 1973 National League pennant, and who remained in a Mets uniform as a coach in the 1980s and their manager in the early ’90s, died on Thursday in East Northport, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin P. Russell
title: A Clash of Civilizations Brought to Life
description: For Álvaro Enrigue, a novelist fascinated with historical detail, the first meeting of the Aztecs and Spanish conquistadors is the obsession of a lifetime. He brings it to life in “You Dreamed of Empires.”
content: The Aug. 13, 2021 edition of The New York Times failed to mention the 500th anniversary of the fall of Tenochtitlan, the erstwhile Aztec capital out of which Mexico City was born. Álvaro Enrigue noticed. Of course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump Rebuked the Judge in His Fraud Trial
description: Also, Bill Belichick is out after 24 years with the Patriots. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: On the final day of his civil fraud trial in Manhattan, Donald Trump unleashed a spate of insults directed at the New York attorney general and the judge overseeing the case. He accused both of them of pursuing their own political agendas and declared himself “an innocent man.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Case for Trump … by Someone Who Wants Him to Lose
description: You can’t defeat an opponent if you refuse to understand what makes him formidable.
content: Barring a political miracle or an act of God, it is overwhelmingly likely that Donald Trump will again be the Republican Party’s nominee for president. Assuming the Democratic nominee in the fall is Joe Biden, polls show Trump with a better-than-even chance of returning to the White House next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Tried to Clean Up His TV Remarks. Social Media Was Another Story.
description: The former president presented a more restrained front on air Wednesday, but he resumed his more incendiary comments soon after.
content: Throughout the last year, former President Donald J. Trump’s rhetoric has been in line with his longstanding impulses. He’s aired his lies about the 2020 election, vowed to be people’s “retribution” if he wins a second term and described undocumented immigrants as “poisoning the blood of our country,” an echo of language used by fascists like Adolf Hitler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Bitcoin Heads to Wall Street. Now What?
description: A new kind of exchange-traded fund linked to the cryptocurrency could begin trading as soon as Thursday, and the investment world is buzzing.
content: A new era of crypto trading is expected to begin as soon as today, after the S.E.C. finally approved the creation of new exchange-traded funds that would allow investors to more easily buy and sell Bitcoin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Is What’s Good for Taylor Tomlinson’s Career Bad for Her Life?
description: The stand-up has a new TV gig and a spot on the list of top-grossing comedy tours. Still, “there sometimes feels like there isn’t anyone my age to talk to.”
content: In September, the night before the comic Taylor Tomlinson made her Radio City Music Hall debut, she called one of her three siblings in tears, asking: “Why do I feel like it’s not enough?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Heiress Seeks 50 Austrians to Give Away $27 Million
description: Marlene Engelhorn has sent invitations to 10,000 Austrians. Once that group is narrowed to 50, it will spend six weekends this year discussing the best way to spend the money.
content: In the coming days, about 10,000 Austrians will find an invitation in their mailboxes from an heiress asking for their help spending 25 million euros, or about $27.4 million, of her inheritance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken Meets With el-Sisi in Egypt to Discuss Plight of Palestinians in Gaza
description: The U.S. secretary of state also planned to talk about how to prevent the violence in the Mideast from escalating further, as Iran-backed militias ramp up attacks.
content: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, met on Thursday with President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt in Cairo to discuss the dire situation of Palestinian civilians in the Israel-Hamas war and what will happen in Gaza when the conflict ends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: ‘Everything Has a Time’: Cleveland’s Longest-Serving Conductor Plans His Departure
description: Franz Welser-Möst, the Cleveland Orchestra’s music director since 2002, is beginning to wind down his career.
content: One night last fall, Franz Welser-Möst, the music director of the Cleveland Orchestra, walked onto the stage of Severance Hall, crossed over to the podium and faced the audience. He was neither solemn nor particularly expressive; he just flashed a Mona Lisa smile before turning to the players and gesturing the downbeat of a Mozart symphony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jinnie Lee
title: How a Former N.F.L. Player Started Designing Sculptural Furniture
description: Plus: hand-painted sweatpants, a chef’s hotel in Seattle and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Michael Bennett, the former N.F.L. player, started designing furniture as a way to reconsider architecture and the spaces that Black people occupy. Inspired by his upbringing in Louisiana and Texas, as well as by trips to Senegal, where his ancestors are from, Bennett began to think about the objects that “bring Black people together in public spaces” as a way to deepen his longtime activism work focused on racial justice. After retiring from football in 2020, he founded the design practice Studio Kër. Bennett’s exploration of the Black home led him to create an 11-piece collection of sculptural furniture that he’s debuting this month in “We Gotta Get Back to the Crib,” his inaugural exhibition for the Los Angeles art gallery Marta, presented at Theaster Gates’s Rebuild Foundation in Chicago. (In the spring, the show will travel to Houston.) The collection reimagines objects of communal gatherings; pieces include the Gumbo lounge chair, a lush take on the stackable monobloc chair, and the Pew couch, a nod to the church bench, made of leather and ekki wood. “For me, the show is about celebrating Black ingenuity and connecting back to that African diasporic design language,” says Bennett. “We Gotta Get Back to the Crib” is on view from Jan. 12 through Feb. 10, marta.la.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen: Iowa, Immunity and Living Well
description: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
content: Hello audiophiles!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘Household Saints’: Miracles on Mulberry Street
description: Nancy Savoca’s 1993 film, a mystical, multigenerational Italian American family saga, opens for a revival run at IFC Center.
content: Nancy Savoca’s 1993 film “Household Saints,” a warmhearted fable spiced with magic realism and zesty performances, may be the most endearing of multigenerational Italian American family sagas and is likely the most mystical. Heavy on folk belief, it flirts with Bresson’s “Diary of a Country Priest” and the divine madness the Greeks called theia mania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and Kate Christobek
title: Trump’s Fraud Trial Draws to an End With Closing Arguments
description: The former president unexpectedly spoke in his own defense, directly attacking New York’s attorney general and the judge overseeing the case.
content: Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud trial concluded on Thursday much as it unfolded over the past three months: in chaos, with the former president insulting the judge to his face, lashing out at the New York attorney general who brought the case and declaring himself “an innocent man.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: When Democracy Is a Threat
description: In its coming elections, Taiwan is voting in China’s shadow.
content: The first time I covered a Taiwan “election,” 38 years ago, the island was a dictatorship under martial law, with members of the opposition more likely to be tortured than to gain power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Patrick Kingsley
title: Blinken Talks a Grand Vision for Mideast Peace but Hits a Wall in Israel
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken conducted marathon diplomacy around the region, but Israeli leaders, focused on war with Hamas, showed no interest in meeting demands like Palestinian statehood.
content: As Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken stood on the tarmac of an airport in Cairo on Thursday before flying back to the United States, he expressed confidence in the support he said he had gotten from leaders across the Middle East for a vision of postwar Gaza, eventually including a Palestinian state alongside Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: At Trial, Sotheby’s Says Russian Oligarch Was Sloppy in Buying Art
description: Dmitry Rybolovlev accused the auction house of aiding a dealer who he says defrauded him in art sales. Sotheby’s says the oligarch spent billions without proper due diligence.
content: As the opening witness in a civil art fraud trial this week, Mikhail Sazonov testified that his employer, a Russian oligarch, had been tricked to overspend by a Swiss art dealer and that those markups had been boosted by the evaluations of artworks supplied by a Sotheby’s executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Inspector General to Investigate Handling of Austin’s Hospitalization
description: The independent review will be conducted in addition to assessments by the defense secretary’s chief of staff and the White House after top officials were not notified of the episode for days.
content: The Pentagon’s inspector general said on Thursday that he would investigate the handling of Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III’s continuing hospitalization, which Mr. Austin and his top aides failed to disclose to President Biden and Congress for days after he developed serious complications from prostate cancer surgery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Suspect Pleads Guilty in 2022 New Year’s Eve Attack on N.Y.P.D. Officers
description: Trevor Bickford, who used a machete to attack an officer near Times Square “in the name of jihad,” pleaded guilty to attempted murder and assault.
content: A man who the authorities said carried out an attempt “in the name of jihad” to kill three New York City police officers near Times Square during the 2022 New Year’s Eve celebration pleaded guilty to federal charges on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Federal Regulator Questions Carmakers About Unwanted Tracking via Their Apps
description: The Federal Communications Commission is concerned about abusive partners using connected car apps to harass and track their victims.
content: Many modern cars are internet-connected and have apps that allow an owner to see a car’s location, turn it on remotely, honk its horn and even adjust the temperature. These apps for car control and tracking are designed for convenience, but a New York Times article last month detailed how they have been weaponized in abusive relationships, allowing for unwanted stalking and harassment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Students Are Saying About New Year’s Resolutions
description: We invited teenagers to weigh in on the practice of setting goals on Jan. 1 and then tell us what plans, if any, they have for 2024.
content: “What will you do — right now, this week, this month — to make a better world?” Roger Rosenblatt asks in the guest essay “This Year, Make a Resolution About Something Bigger Than Yourself.” Rather than making the self-oriented promises typical of New Year’s resolutions, he suggests turning our attention to others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Why Bill Belichick Fit In So Well, for So Long, in New England
description: The head coach of the Patriots, who has parted ways with the team after 24 years, won six Super Bowls with a taciturn approach that rewarded performance over potential.
content: It is hard to make an impression, and even harder to make history in a place as old and momentous as New England. The measuring stick is so high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden Campaign to Send Top Allies to Iowa to Spread Democrats’ Message
description: The Hollywood mogul Jeffrey Katzenberg, Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois and Senator Tina Smith of Minnesota are expected to appear on Monday, as Republicans hold their caucuses.
content: Iowa is dominated by Republicans right now. The events by presidential candidates are for Republicans, the voters who come to see them are Republicans and the main event, Monday’s caucuses, will feature Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Subway Delayed Again? Might Be Caused by a Brake Prank.
description: Each year, hundreds of subway riders pull the emergency brake for no good reason. Last week, that kind of vandalism led to a derailment that injured dozens.
content: The collision between two subway trains that injured dozens of people in Manhattan last week began with what has become a routine problem in New York City’s mass transit system — pranksters pulling emergency brakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Walther
title: For the Sake of College Athletes Everywhere, Jim Harbaugh Should Remain at Michigan
description: Let’s hope this stubborn, delightful man stays where he is.
content: Some 25 million Americans watched with heavenly joy (or as the case may be, in Ohio, infernal dread) as the Michigan Wolverines defeated the Washington Huskies in the college football national championship on Monday. This was Michigan’s first national title since 1997, and only its second since 1948.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold, Sydney Harper, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Summer Thomad, Diana Nguyen, Patricia Willens, Michael Benoist, Dan Powell, Will Reid and Chris Wood
title: The Threat of a Wider War in the Middle East
description: A string of attacks have heightened fears that the war in Gaza could become a regional conflict.
content: A recent string of attacks across the Middle East has raised concerns that the war between Hamas and Israel is spreading, and might put pressure on other countries like Iran and the United States to get more involved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Top Natural Gas Producers Announce Multibillion-Dollar Merger
description: The deal, between Chesapeake Energy and Southwestern Energy, would create one of the largest energy producers in the United States.
content: Chesapeake Energy and Southwestern Energy, two of the largest natural gas producers in the United States, announced plans to merge on Thursday, in an all-stock deal worth $7.4 billion. The new company would become one of the largest energy producers in the United States, with a significant presence in Louisiana and Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: How a Congressman Wants to Honor Roberto Clemente
description: The right fielder for the Pittsburgh Pirates deserves to be commemorated with a coin, Representative Adriano Espaillat says.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out why a congressman from the Bronx is pressing for a coin to commemorate a baseball player from the Pittsburgh Pirates. We’ll also see what to expect as Donald Trump’s civil fraud trial moves into its final phase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Hertz Will Shrink Electric Fleet After Being Burned by Tesla’s Price Cuts
description: The rental car company blamed the sharp drop in the value of electric vehicles and higher repair costs for its decision to sell 20,000 cars.
content: The rental car company Hertz will be selling about one-third of the electric vehicles in its fleet after they lost value more quickly than expected, the company said on Thursday. The drop in value is a blow to the company’s efforts to replace gasoline vehicles with cars that do not produce tailpipe emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A TV Drama Finally Forces Action on Britain’s Post Office Scandal
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 11, 2023.
content: “Everyone likes an underdog, and we had underdogs in spades.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Send In the Beans
description: Swap in beans for protein-rich, vegetarian takes on classic dishes: beans Marbella, beans and greens alla vodka, and Buffalo white beans.
content: A couple of weeks ago, I was having drinks with some friends when one of them uttered an absolutely baffling phrase: “beans alla gin with oat milk.” I laughed so hard I was moved to tears. What, pray tell, were beans alla gin with oat milk?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Driving Madeleine’ Review: A Nonagenarian in Paris
description: The beloved French singer Line Renaud plays a woman who forms an unlikely bond with a surly cabdriver in this heart-warmer.
content: A prickly cabdriver gains perspective thanks to a chatty nonagenarian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fresh Inflation Data Shows Intact, but Bumpy, Cool-Down
description: Inflation remains faster than usual — and month-to-month bumps are still likely as volatile prices fluctuate — but it is making progress back toward a normal pace.
content: Consumer price data released Thursday showed Federal Reserve officials, the White House and American households that inflation continued to slow at the end of 2023, capping a year in which the price increases bedeviling families and policymakers cooled in earnest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Sagen
title: Sweetie, I’ll Be Back at 2 A.M.
description: Some parents, anxious about their child staying in someone else’s home, are choosing “sleepunders” — picking kids up just before bedtime — or even staying over with them.
content: Brianna Michaud’s ’90s childhood was filled with sleepovers at friends’ houses. Her mother sometimes came inside the house and chatted with the parents for a few minutes, but sensitive topics like bodily autonomy, gun safety or technology use — except for the rule that she not watch anything rated PG-13 or higher — weren’t the kinds of things discussed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Awards Voters Hit the Tape (or YouTube Highlights)
description: Deciding who should be M.V.P. or make an All-Pro team means keeping up with 272 three-hour television episodes a season.
content: On the Sundays that Peter King is not reporting at a football stadium, he watches television from home in Brooklyn, switching between the most important afternoon game and NFL RedZone, a channel that showcases various games during their most dramatic moments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Johanna Lemola
title: Finland Extends Closure of Border With Russia
description: Late last year, Finland accused Moscow of facilitating an influx of migrants and shut its land border crossings with Russia.
content: Finland said on Thursday that it would keep its eastern border with Russia closed for another month amid an ongoing dispute about increased numbers of migrants in the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin, Hiba Yazbek and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel Faces Accusation of Genocide as South Africa Brings Case to U.N. Court
description: Arguing to a packed courtroom at the International Court of Justice in The Hague, South African lawyers cited the words of Israeli officials as evidence in their case. Israel has categorically denied the accusation.
content: After three months besieging and bombarding the Gaza Strip in its war against Hamas, Israel faced a charge of genocide at the International Court of Justice on Thursday, as South Africa argued that Israel “means to create conditions of death” in Gaza, and demanded the court order an emergency suspension of the military campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Can Dieting Actually Lead to Long-Term Weight Loss?
description: We asked experts to explain what diets can (and can’t) do for our health.
content: Dieting has long been viewed as the path to smaller bodies and better health. Stick to the right diet, the $75 billion U.S. weight loss industry may have you think, and you, too, can lose weight and keep it off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Purina Rebuts TikTok Rumors About Pet Food Safety
description: As reports of dog illnesses linked to Purina’s Pro Plan food caused a stir on TikTok in recent weeks, a Purina spokeswoman said that the rumors “are not true and that our food is safe to feed.”
content: Purina has been forced to rebut what it described as “online rumors” that have caused a frenzy on TikTok in recent weeks alleging that its Pro Plan food had sickened dozens of pets, mostly dogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Seeing Isamu Noguchi Through Someone Else’s Eyes
description: Marie Menken’s film ‘‘Visual Variations on Noguchi,’’ shot nearly 80 years ago in the sculptor’s Greenwich Village atelier, has never shown at his namesake museum — until now.
content: One of the more revolutionary works of art on display in New York right now is a four-minute-long film nearly 80 years old. Called “Visual Variations on Noguchi,” it was shot in Isamu Noguchi’s Greenwich Village studio sometime in 1945 or ’46. Wielding the camera was Marie Menken, a Brooklyn-born daughter of Lithuanian immigrants who had, until this studio visit, chiefly been a painter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Apolonia, Apolonia’ Review: A Whole Life in Art
description: The painter Apolonia Sokol is the ostensible subject of a wide-ranging documentary about life itself.
content: “For as long as I can remember, I’ve seen the world through my camera,” a woman’s voice says in the early moments of “Apolonia, Apolonia.” Onscreen, we’re watching — presumably through that same camera — a young woman, strong features, entrancing smile, dark circles under her eyes, bearing the expression of a person who’s not afraid of the lens one bit. “But no motif,” the voice continues, “has caught my eye as she did.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Elton John’s First Auction in 21 Years Has It All: Boots to Banksy.
description: The 900 items from his Atlanta home include blue-chip art by Julian Schnabel and Richard Avedon, Versace dinnerware and flamboyant costumes.
content: Elton John is downsizing — and the superstar’s former penthouse residence in Atlanta has been emptied for a series of auctions at Christie’s starting on Feb. 21. The items are expected to bring in an estimated $10 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Newsom Seeks to Close $37.9 Billion Deficit by Cutting Spending and Using Reserves
description: California is among several states tightening their belts in the post-pandemic economy.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced on Wednesday that California had a $37.9 billion budget deficit and asked state lawmakers to cover the shortfall by trimming spending and drawing down reserves in an election year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Prays That Trump Can Deliver
description: “That is a terrible idea, and please, Jesus, let it happen,” Colbert said of the former president’s initial desire to deliver his own closing argument in his fraud trial.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Edward Jay Epstein, Author and Stubborn Skeptic, Dies at 88
description: He questioned the findings of the Warren Commission, called Edward Snowden a prized Russian asset and exposed the diamond industry’s economic impact.
content: Edward Jay Epstein, an iconoclastic author whose deeply researched books challenged conventional wisdom about controversies ranging from whether John F. Kennedy was killed by a lone assassin to whether the whistle-blower Edward Snowden was really a Russian spy, has died in Manhattan. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Discord Cuts 17% of Workers in Latest Tech Layoffs
description: In an internal memo, Discord said it had grown five times its size since 2020.
content: Discord, the social chat and messaging start-up beloved by gamers, told employees on Thursday that it would cut 17 percent of its staff, adding to the string of recent jobs reductions by tech firms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Fruit Stripe Gum, Famous for Short Bursts of Flavor, Is Discontinued
description: Its disappearance from store shelves after more than 50 years invited nostalgic posts on social media. “Best two seconds of flavor you’ve ever had,” one person wrote on Reddit.
content: Fruit Stripe, the striped chewing gum known for its short burst of flavor, has been discontinued after more than a half-century, inspiring nostalgic tributes across social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: What We Learned From Bogotá’s Buses
description: Transformative projects don’t conform to election cycles. They’re not the work of any single person.
content: Recently, I traveled to Bogotá, Colombia, which is twice the size of New York, to report on a transit system that was once the envy of cities around the world. The system, a rapid bus network called TransMilenio, rolled out in 2000. Its buses weren’t as big or as fast as trains, but they were up and running in a fraction of the time and at a vastly lower cost. Millions of residents living in far-flung, formerly disconnected slums suddenly gained access to jobs and schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What You’re Looking Forward to in 2024
description: Graduating from Harvard, trips abroad, a 75th birthday and more.
content: January is a month for feeling hopeful. The year is new and offering us all a chance to re-evaluate and reset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: The Effects of a Tough Workout
description: Damon Gulczynski pulls a bait and switch on us.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Cockpit Recording’s Erasure Hampers Boeing 737 Max 9 Investigation
description: Cockpit voice recorders in the U.S. start rerecording every two hours, a limit that the National Transportation Safety Board says should be extended to 25 hours.
content: Officials investigating why a panel on a Boeing 737 Max 9 blew open during an Alaska Airlines flight last week say they are struggling to piece together exactly what happened because the plane’s cockpit voice recorder overwrote itself before it could be retrieved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Israel Adesanya, M.M.A. Star, Narrowly Avoids Drunk-Driving Conviction
description: Within hours, the former middleweight mixed martial arts champion risked more legal trouble by posting provocative content on social media.
content: Just weeks after being charged with driving under the influence in Auckland, New Zealand, last year, Israel Adesanya, a former two-time middleweight mixed martial arts champion, sought to project humility and remorse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: A Convicted Criminal as the Nominee? Trump’s Rivals Avoid Even Raising It
description: The former president’s legal jeopardy offers an obvious line of attack for Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis, but fearing voter blowback, that cudgel remains largely unused.
content: It is an obvious line of attack that has been creeping into the arsenal of rivals trying to stop former President Donald J. Trump ahead of the Iowa caucuses on Monday — if nominated to be the Republican Party’s White House standard-bearer, the former president could very well be a convicted criminal by Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Self Reliance’ Review: Find a Friend, Save a Life
description: In this fleetingly amusing comedy, a lonely loser becomes the target of reality-show killers.
content: The R rating awarded to “Self Reliance” for its language only proves the heavy-handedness of our rating system, as you’ll strain to hear anything in this genially bonkers comedy that couldn’t have been written by an 11-year-old. Which is exactly the age group most likely to enjoy it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Settlers’ Review: Writing the History of Modern Chile, in Blood
description: This harrowing drama takes place in Tierra del Fuego, an archipelago in the southernmost part of South America, in 1901.
content: Not long after the Chilean film “The Settlers” opens — after the first shot has been fired and the first blood spilled — an aristocratic-looking horseman rides up to some workers on a grassy plain. Wearing a wide-brim hat and a mustache, a scarf around his neck, he settles into a spacious tent. There, seated at a desk set on a handsome rug, he summons his foreman, whom he instructs to find a route to the Atlantic for his sheep. To accomplish this, he coolly explains, “you will have to clean the island” — a grotesque, civilized euphemism for murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: New Origin Story for Tyrannosaurus Rex Suggested by Fossil
description: Researchers say the species they named Tyrannosaurus mcraeensis predated the dinosaur era’s great predator.
content: A team of researchers have announced the discovery of a new species of Tyrannosaurus from New Mexico, one that appeared in the fossil record five million to seven million years before the familiar tyrant lizard. Their research, published Thursday in the journal Scientific Reports, suggests a new chapter could be added to the origin story of Tyrannosaurus rex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: F.A.A. Investigating Whether Boeing 737 Max 9 Conformed to Approved Design
description: Regulators are examining whether Boeing complied with safety rules on a plane that lost a fuselage panel while in flight last week.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Thursday that it had opened an investigation into whether Boeing failed to ensure that its 737 Max 9 plane was safe and manufactured to match the design approved by the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Jan. 24, 2024
description: Congress has tended to be slow to respond to revolutionary technologies. How long do you think it will take to regulate artificial intelligence?
content: This graph was previously published in The New York Times, five months after President Biden announced the voluntary commitments by seven of the major A.I. companies to standards of safety, security and trust to manage the risks associated with this emerging technology. Currently, there is no agreement on enforceable regulations for A.I. companies or A.I.-generated materials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Inshallah a Boy’ Review: Where the Male Line Is the Only Line
description: In this film by Amjad Al Rasheed, a young widow in Jordan strains against the tradition, underpinned by law, that without a man she is nothing.
content: Before things take an unjust turn in Amjad Al Rasheed’s tense and accomplished directorial debut, “Inshallah a Boy,” a wife and husband lie in bed discussing the timing to conceive a second child. There is something sweet in the exhaustion of the husband, Adnan (Mohammad Suleiman), and surprising in his admission to his wife, Nawal (Mouna Hawa), that he’s the cause of their fertility issues. This promising exchange will be their last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Saban, Never Showy, Almost Always Successful, Leaves a Legacy Beyond Football
description: Alabama’s longtime football coach won more national championships than anyone in modern history and helped change the image of the state.
content: Throughout a national era of disillusionment, institutional failure and turmoil, Alabama football, of all things, has been a machine of astonishing consistency, humming for nearly two decades at peak performance.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 11, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Jan. 11, 2024.
content: An article on Wednesday about the Federal Aviation Administration’s decision to delay safety inspections of Boeing’s 737 Max 9 referred incorrectly to the feedback that prompted a revision of inspection instructions for the airliners. The F.A.A. said the changes were based on feedback the manufacturer had received, but it did not say that the feedback came from the agency.
